description: A handful of oddly-shaped worthless bits of abstract code.  Seeing this is a bug.
A handful of oddly-shaped valuable bits of abstract code.  Seeing this is a bug.
Primitive yarn made from coarse plant fibers like straw or grass.  Too thick to sew with, but could be woven into a crude sheet of fabric.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of cotton, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of, but they can be recycled into some thread if you really want.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of faux fur, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of.

A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of felt, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of, but they can be recycled into some wool fiber if you really want.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of fur, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of.

A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of Kevlar fabric, waste material from tailoring projects.  Normally it would be disposed of, but since Kevlar is very difficult to make in a post-apocalyptic world, it might be worth recycling it for Kevlar thread.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of leather, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of Lycra, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of neoprene, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of.
A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of synthetic fabric, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of.

A handful of oddly-shaped smallish bits of heat-resistant Nomex fabric, waste material from tailoring projects.  Normally it would be disposed of, but since Nomex is very difficult to make in a post-apocalyptic world, it might be worth recycling it for Nomex thread.
A misshapen section of loose carpet.  Not useful for much on its own and can be discarded.
A small bolt of fur from an animal, roughly six inches square.  Can be made into patchwork fur sheets or used to repair fur fabric.
A small bolt of garishly-colored faux fur, roughly six inches square.  Can be made into patchwork faux fur sheets or used to repair faux fur fabric.
A roughly six-inch square patch of leather, could be used to repair clothing and make smaller leather crafts.
A small, six-inch square patch of felt.
A six-inch square patch of Nomex fire-resistant fabric.
A rolled-up animal hide which has been scraped of extraneous hair and flesh and treated to prevent decay.  It still requires tanning to become usable leather.
A folded 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of leather made from carefully tanned animal hide.  Can be cut up or used as is.
A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of leather.  Can be cut up or used as is.
A folded 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of leather sewn together from patches.  Can be cut up or used as is.
A rolled-up animal hide which has been scraped of extraneous hair and flesh and treated to prevent decay.  It still requires tanning to become usable fur.
A folded sheet of fur made from carefully tanned animal pelt.  Can be cut up or used as is.
A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of fur sewn together from patches.  Can be cut up or used as is.
A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of cotton fabric, suitable for making clothing.  You can use it to stop bleeding, but it is very wasteful.
//: Medium weight cotton fabric with a GSM of 203

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of cotton sewn together from patches of various clothing parts.  Suitable for making clothing if you lack proper material sheets.
A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of colorful faux fur, suitable for making clothing.
//: Based on 2000gsm faux fur

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of faux fur sewn together from mismatched patches.  Suitable for making clothing if you lack proper material sheets, but the bright, clashing colors might end up making you look like a diseased Muppet.
//: 12 inches by 24 inches with GSM of 2000

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of felt, suitable for making clothing.
//: based on 150GSM felt

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of felt sewn together from patches.  Suitable for making clothing if you lack proper material sheets.
//: 150GSM felt

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of loose-woven Kevlar synthetic fabric, suitable for making durable cut and stab resistant clothing.  While protective, this kind of Kevlar is not suitable for making ballistic gear due to the difference in weave tightness.
//: values taken from Duponts chemical reference. 144 GSM

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of fabric sewn together from Kevlar patches, suitable for making durable cut and stab resistant clothing.  This would be out of the question for ballistic Kevlar but the simpler, looser weave of this variety means it is fine to use if you lack proper material sheets.
//: values taken from Duponts chemical reference. 144 GSM

description: A 6-inch square patch of loose-woven Kevlar, suitable for repairing cut and stab resistant clothing or reassembling into a patchwork sheet for sewing.
//: values taken from Duponts chemical reference. 144 GSM

description: A sheet of synthetic fabric blended with stretchy Lycra fibers, suitable for making flexible, yet strong clothing.
//: 180 GSM fabric

description: A small, 16-layer thick ballistic Kevlar panel.  This kind of Kevlar is precision-made by machine and features an extremely tight weave which cannot be replicated by hand.  Due to this, any damage incurred to your ballistic armor will necessitate complete replacement with a new panel.  It is not as effective as loose-woven Kevlar at stopping stab wounds, but it has no equal against the threat posed by firearms.
//: 12 inch by 24 inch sheets, 16 layers thick. Values actually nearly identically matched panels available for purchase.

description: A compressed panel of Kevlar treated with epoxy or other adhesive.  It could be used to repair items made of rigid Kevlar, and makes a decent substitute for damaged carbon fiber and the like even if it isn't exactly the same.
//: same as above but adding superglue. IRL this is how they are made, though using 2 part resin instead.

description: A 12-inch by 24-inch sheet of fabric sewn together from Lycra patches.  Suitable for making flexible, yet strong clothing if you lack proper material sheets.
//: 180GSM

description: A sheet of neoprene, a synthetic rubber, suitable for making underwater gear.
//: 110GSM, 1mm thick neoprene

description: A sheet of neoprene sewn together from patches, with waterproofed seams.  Suitable for making underwater gear if you lack proper material sheets.
//: Density of 1.23 grams per mL

description: A sheet of Nomex synthetic fabric, suitable for making heat-resistant clothing.
//: Taken from duponts chemical reference sheets. 170GSM

description: A sheet of Nomex synthetic fabric, sewn together from patches using Nomex thread.  Suitable for making heat-resistant clothing if you lack proper material sheets.
//: Taken from duponts chemical reference sheets. 170GSM

description: A sheet of synthetic fabric, suitable for making clothing.
//: .25mm thick, 288 GSM (nylon 6,6 ranges 250-300 gsm)
//1: 1x2' sheet is 1858 cm^2 and at 288 gsm gives listed weight; density of 1.14g/cm^3 suggests about .25 mm thickness per sheet

description: A sheet of fabric, sewn together from synthetic fabric patches in a patchwork fashion.  Suitable for making most clothing, though it's much less time-efficient than if using proper material sheets.
//: .25mm thick, 288 GSM (nylon 6,6 ranges 250-300 gsm)
//1: 1x2' sheet is 1858 cm^2 and at 288 gsm gives listed weight; density of 1.14g/cm^3 suggests about .25 mm thickness per sheet

description: A pile of shredded fabric, dry grass, hair or other cheap materials which could be used to stuff the fabric layers of a gambeson to create armor more cheaply and easily than properly layering and quilting the entire product.

Very durable Kevlar thread that would be particularly useful for making ballistic armor, though it's fine to use in place of normal thread too, in most cases.  Making armor-grade Kevlar sheets from this would need a particularly tight weave, and so would require some specialized machinery.
//: 30 meters of thread per 1g, roughly 6 inches of thread per unit.

description: Heat-resistant Nomex thread that would be particularly useful for making heat protection gear, though it's fine to use in place of normal thread too, in most cases.
//: 30 meters of thread per 1g, roughly 6 inches of thread per unit.

description: A 12 inch by 24 inch sheet of durable blue denim, suitable for making jeans, jorts, or jirts.
//: Usually lightweight 10-12 oz denim.

description: Oddly-shaped smallish denim patches, waste material from tailoring projects.
A small, 6 inch square patch of blue denim.  It could be used to repair items made of denim or stitched into patchwork sheets for tailoring projects.
A selection of various sections of denim, sewn together in a patchwork fashion.  Suitable for tailoring, though it's much less time-efficient than if using proper material sheets.
A 12 inch by 24 inch sheet of durable and waterproof waxed canvas fabric, suitable for making tough bags and clothing.
//: heavyweight cotton canvas with a GSM of 406
//1: 1x2' sheet is 1858 cm^2 and at 406 gsm gives listed weight; density of 1.6g/cm^3 suggests about .254 mm thickness per sheet - rounded down to .250

description: Some tough canvas-weight thread, sturdier than ordinary thread.  You could meticulously weave this into a sheet of canvas cloth.  It would also be useful for stitching such sheets together, though it's fine to use for normal tailoring projects too.
//: 30 meters of thread per 1g, roughly 6 inches of thread per unit.

description: Oddly-shaped smallish bits of canvas, waste material from tailoring projects.  Not useful for much and usually disposed of, but can be recycled into some tough thread.
A small, 6 inch square patch of tough canvas.  It could be used to repair items made of canvas or stitched into patchwork sheets for tailoring projects.
//: Roughly 406 GSM cotton, with a size of 6 inches square

description: A selection of various sections of canvas, sewn together in a patchwork fashion.  Suitable for tailoring, though it's much less time-efficient than if using proper material sheets.
//: heavyweight cotton canvas with a GSM of 406
//1: 1x2' sheet is 1858 cm^2 and at 406 gsm gives listed weight; density of 1.6g/cm^3 suggests about .254 mm thickness per sheet - rounded down to .250
